alert.note: Alert for Johnson (Wyoming) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Advisory issued June 07 at 5:57PM MDT until June 11 at 12:00PM MDT by NWS Riverton
info.description: .Showers and thunderstorms from earlier Wednesday afternoon produced very heavy rain in the North Fork Powder River drainage around Mayoworth. The rain has caused minor flooding. Water levels have risen quickly on the tributaries and main stem North Fork, which has been running bankfull or even out of its banks in spots. Other creeks emerging from the east slopes of the Bighorn Range may also be experiencing minor flooding. ...FLOOD ADVISORY NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL 8 PM MDT THIS EVENING... * WHAT...Small stream flooding and flooding of normally dry draws caused by excessive rainfall continues. * WHERE...A portion of north central Wyoming, including the following county, Johnson. * WHEN...Until 800 PM MDT. * IMPACTS...Rises in small streams and normally dry draws. Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas. In addition to minor flooding on the North Fork Powder River, Martin Draw, Willow Creek, and Pass Creek could also be experiencing minor flooding. Much of the runoff from the heaviest rain should drain into the North Fork Powder River just before it crosses under State Highway 191 for the last time just northwest of Kaycee. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 552 PM MDT, Rapid river rises on the North Fork Powder River will cause minor flooding in the advisory area. Between 1.5 and 2.5 inches was estimated to have fallen earlier Wednesday. - Additional rainfall amounts up to 0.25 inches are expected later Wednesday evening, but there should be a period of drier weather through at least 7 PM. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Mayoworth and the North Fork Powder River drainage.
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law enforcement and request they pass this information to the National Weather Service when you can do so safely.
